Welcome to the fascinating world of **waves** - the carriers of energy through space and matter!

## What you'll learn:
- **Wave Properties** - Frequency, wavelength, amplitude
- **Sound Waves** - How we hear and the Doppler effect
- **Light Behavior** - Reflection and refraction
- **Lenses and Mirrors** - Image formation

> ğŸ’¡ **Fun Fact:** Light can behave as both a wave AND a particle - one of quantum physics' greatest mysteries!

| Type | Medium Required | Examples |
|------|-----------------|----------|
| Mechanical | Yes | Sound, water waves |
| Electromagnetic | No | Light, radio, X-rays |
| Matter | Yes | Electron waves |

Let's ride the waves of physics!

slides.title: The Doppler Effect
slides.content:
# The Doppler Effect ğŸš—

The **Doppler effect** is the change in observed frequency when source and observer are in relative motion.

## Everyday Experience

```
ğŸš—â†’â†’â†’  (approaching)  â†’â†’â†’ ğŸ‘‚
  High pitch (compressed waves)

ğŸš—â†’â†’â†’  (receding)  â†â†â† ğŸ‘‚
  Low pitch (stretched waves)
```

## The Doppler Formula

```
f' = f Ã— (v Â± v_observer) / (v âˆ“ v_source)
```

| Motion | Observer | Source |
|--------|----------|--------|
| Approaching | + (top) | - (bottom) |
| Receding | - (top) | + (bottom) |

## Applications

| Field | Application |
|-------|-------------|
| **Medicine** | Doppler ultrasound (blood flow) |
| **Astronomy** | Redshift/blueshift of stars |
| **Weather** | Doppler radar (storm tracking) |
| **Police** | Speed guns |
| **Astronomy** | Measuring galaxy velocities |

## Redshift and Blueshift

- **Blueshift:** Object approaching â†’ Higher frequency (blue)
- **Redshift:** Object receding â†’ Lower frequency (red)

### Hubble's Discovery
Distant galaxies are **redshifted** â†’ Universe is expanding!

## Example

**An ambulance siren at 700 Hz approaches at 30 m/s. What frequency do you hear? (v_sound = 340 m/s)**

f' = 700 Ã— (340)/(340 - 30) = 700 Ã— (340/310) = **768 Hz**

> ğŸ¯ **Remember:** Approaching = Higher frequency, Receding = Lower frequency

## Types of Reflection

### Specular (Regular) Reflection
- Smooth surfaces (mirrors, still water)
- Parallel rays stay parallel
- Forms clear images

### Diffuse Reflection
- Rough surfaces (paper, walls)
- Rays scatter in many directions
- No clear image, but we see the object

## Plane Mirrors

| Property | Description |
|----------|-------------|
| Image type | Virtual |
| Image size | Same as object |
| Image position | Same distance behind mirror |
| Orientation | Laterally inverted |

## Curved Mirrors

### Concave (Converging)
- Curves inward (like a cave)
- Real or virtual images
- Uses: Makeup mirrors, telescopes, headlights

### Convex (Diverging)
- Curves outward
- Always virtual, diminished images
- Uses: Rear-view mirrors, security mirrors

# Refraction of Light ğŸ’

## What is Refraction?

Refraction is the **bending of light** when it passes from one medium to another.

## Why Light Bends

Light changes speed in different media:
- Faster in less dense media (air)
- Slower in denser media (glass, water)

```
    Air (fast)
    \  Î¸â‚
     \ â†“
â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â—â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
       â†˜ Î¸â‚‚
    Glass (slow)
```

## Snell's Law

```
nâ‚ sin(Î¸â‚) = nâ‚‚ sin(Î¸â‚‚)
```

## Refractive Index (n)

```
n = c/v = speed of light in vacuum / speed in medium
```

| Medium | n |
|--------|---|
| Vacuum | 1.00 |
| Air | 1.0003 |
| Water | 1.33 |
| Glass | 1.5 |
| Diamond | 2.42 |

## Bending Direction Rules

| Light going to... | Bends... |
|-------------------|----------|
| Denser medium (â†‘n) | Toward normal |
| Less dense medium (â†“n) | Away from normal |

## Real World Examples

| Phenomenon | Explanation |
|------------|-------------|
| Straw in water | Looks bent due to refraction |
| Swimming pool | Pool looks shallower |
| Mirage | Hot air bends light |
| Rainbow | Dispersion in water droplets |

> ğŸ¯ **Key Point:** Higher refractive index = greater bending!

## What is TIR?

## Conditions for TIR

Interference occurs when two or more waves **overlap** in the same region.

## Principle of Superposition

> *When waves meet, the resultant displacement is the sum of individual displacements.*

# Polarization ğŸ•¶ï¸

## What is Polarization?

Polarization restricts light waves to vibrate in **one plane only**.

## Unpolarized vs Polarized Light

```
Unpolarized:        Polarized:
     â†•               â†•
   â†™ â†—             only
   â†â†’               â†•
   â†– â†˜               â†•
(all directions)   (one direction)
```

## Only Transverse Waves Polarize!

Longitudinal waves (like sound) cannot be polarized - this proves light is a transverse wave.

## Methods of Polarization

| Method | How it works |
|--------|-------------|
| **Filters** | Absorb all but one direction |
| **Reflection** | Reflected light is partially polarized |
| **Refraction** | Double refraction in crystals |
| **Scattering** | Skylight is partially polarized |

## Malus's Law

When polarized light passes through a polarizer at angle Î¸:

```
I = Iâ‚€ cosÂ²(Î¸)
```

| Angle | Transmitted |
|-------|------------|
| 0Â° | 100% |
| 45Â° | 50% |
| 90Â° | 0% (crossed polarizers) |

## Applications

| Application | How Polarization Helps |
|-------------|------------------------|
| **Sunglasses** | Reduce glare from reflections |
| **LCD screens** | Control light transmission |
| **3D movies** | Different polarization for each eye |
| **Photography** | Reduce reflections, enhance sky |
| **Stress analysis** | Reveals internal stress patterns |

> ğŸ¯ **Key Point:** Polarization is definitive proof that light is a transverse wave!

### Vision Defects

## Microscope

Two convex lenses for high magnification:

```
M_total = M_objective Ã— M_eyepiece
```

## Telescope

### Refracting Telescope
- Uses lenses
- Objective lens gathers light
- Eyepiece magnifies image

### Reflecting Telescope
- Uses curved mirror as objective
- Larger apertures possible
- Most large telescopes are reflectors

## Magnifying Power

```
M = f_objective / f_eyepiece
```

## Resolution Limit

Diffraction limits the finest detail visible:

| Instrument | Resolution |
|------------|------------|
| Human eye | ~0.1 mm |
| Light microscope | ~200 nm |
| Electron microscope | ~0.1 nm |
